comments.commentBody:
This is one that the official Lego website and the Merriam-Webster people don't get to make a call on. Legos are Legos. Dump out a box of them to start building with, they are Legos, not Lego - there is no kid with a bucket of them, no parent who bought them, who doesn't know the word is "Legos" (and not "Lego bricks" - especially not nowadays when half of them are not bricks in the least).

I like that Martin Freeman / Stephen Colbert story. Legolas, in Tolkien's elvish language, means (shining-) green leaf (his name is sometimes rendered that way, Legolas Greenleaf.

replies.commentBody: Yes we changed it, thanks. I misunderstood Negan's line toward the end about leaving Rick's group a truck.
Ah, so I've been defending you after the fact!  :)

comments.commentBody:
Inherited a new RV?!? Um, did you miss the part in last season's finale where they got out of the RV to walk, then Eugene drives off alone to "distract" the Saviors? When Rick and the others arrive on the scene, Eugene is already on his knees in front of the RV...

It's the same vehicle. The Saviors took it when they captured Eugene. Rick drives off in it at the end. Same RV as always, not an additional one.
Sick.

With the show aligned with the comic, and after six seasons of watching this Hobbesian state of nature, you think you can't bear to watch any more? Sure, we're going to have to suffer thru probably an entire season of Rick going all Cool Hand Luke fetching the shot turtle, but you don't have to be a cannibal to know he's going to eventually get his game on and make good on that promise (yet again); preferably with that leftover RPG, tho the smart money is on Negan getting his ax back.
(For my part, I'd have taken the arm and had Maggie kill herself once they were set "free" just to keep the piling-on of the first half of the show going; it would have taken the scripting from exceptional to epic.)

John sf......your first sentence, that no one in China likes Ai Wei Wei, is an untrustworthy and delusional opinion without any basis in fact.
To clarify your understanding,Ai,is an artist that searches for the "real"in the human condition without regard to '"east"and "west"or political philosophy...........his "Red Line"can symbolize the plutocrat communist elites in China that pretend to rule as the "proletariat masses".......or the capitalist "bottom line" of profit which defines the institutionalized opportunistic corruption of politics in the west.
The right to freely criticize your government(whose parameters are always changing) is essential to life,liberty and the pursuit of happiness........and to understand who is in charge!

Many people believe laowai enjoys/ed more privilege than Chinese do, for they at least are not bound and stratified and even flagrantly discriminated against according to their Hukou in China. This new policy may seem to be unjust to foreigners, yet it on the other hand may aim to achieve an equality between foreigners and Chinese on Chinese land. Shared inequality is not inequality, as the Chinese idiom goes.

I watched the video after posting. I gasped when I saw that the woman was so caught up in her encounter with her assailant that she followed him out of the lift and left her child in there alone...and the doors closed! Of course it is horrible to see a man punching a woman, but where were that woman's priorities? Was her right to have a smoke-free lift ride more important than the safety of her child?

Another helpful article:
http://www.rte.ie/radio/mooneygoeswild/pdf/How%20Doctors%20Die.pdf

“It’s for strong-willed, independent people with very supportive families,” said Dr. Timothy Quill, a veteran palliative care physician at the University of Rochester Medical Center. I'm a strong-willed, independent person with no support at all. This article is a lifesaver (pun intended). If I can find a way to write my power-of-attorney or primary care physician to find my body in my home without their interfering with my VSED choice, I will die a happy death indeed.

Bingo!  What you have articulated very well is true of many consumable products and services.  Why does something cost so much?, because too much money is being charged for the particular product or service.  And why is too much money being charged?, well, . . . Because the product producer or service provider can, and will do so for as long as they can get away with it.  The answer in the short run sometimes is don't buy the product

Love the wine.
Hate the houses. Greed, pure and simple.
Decent (read : average) years see the price pushed up. Because they can.
Good years see even more of an increase in purchase price. Because they can.
Then a better than average year sees the price go through the roof.
Forget the issue of drink ability or needing to hold the wine for decades to truly appreciate it.
The houses could easily produce affordable, drinkable wines if they chose.
But that will never happen because they're afraid that might impact the price of their premium labels. Greed.
Even more than having the show back, I'm excited that your recaps have returned, Jeremy! Can't wait to read the extended review.
Same thought!
I also just deleted it from my DVR lineup.   Great premise when it started, but it has devolved into something pretty pathetic.
Ditto

After forcing myself to finish the episode, I deleted The Walking Dead (and Talking Dead) from my DVR.  As much as I like the actors (Jeffrey Dean Morgan killed it, no pun intended), I just don't care about what happens to the rest of the characters.  If I want to watch a show about a bleak and hopeless dystopia, I'll just keep watching the election news.
Carl seemed to have a better grasp of the situation than either Darryl or Rick. Maybe he remembered Stan Grossman from Fargo. "We aren't holding any cards here, Wade."
It took a while but I have come to the same conclusion.  I guess I'm not one of those people who gets enjoyment from seeing the worst of humanity.
Torture porn.

loved chiller theater, i grew up in north hills, so nice to see the chilly billy reference. people here dont get it, i love the show, yea life is not good with no law and order, its what life would be, dark and scary

Washington County here - loved Bill Cardille and getting scared out of my wits Saturday nights growing up!  Saw the black and white Night of the Living Dead (he plays the "Are they slow-moving, Chief?" reporter as Romero used local characters in his films) on Chiller Theater and had nightmares for years!  I don't think the little girl killing her mother with a trowel in the basement was much worse than this episode...

I've been a fan of Zombie tales since I was a kid watching Chiller Theater on Channel 11, way back when. My kids and all my hip friends are devotees of The Walking Dead, but I cannot get into this show, no matter how I try. I think that the author of this article sums it up for me in the first paragraph: "Six seasons in, “The Walking Dead” had become repetitive ." Okay, I'm ready for my clubbing, Negan!
I agree 100% I am done with this show. They crossed a line and I have no interest in watching it again.
I am done with this show, the writers have just gone too far.  I will never watch it again.
I ALWAYS DVR the show and at 10:06 watch it scanning through the commercials. Takes less than 45 minutes to see it all.

There are always too many commercials--it was the same with Mad Men.  Do yourself a favor and DVR it so you can fast forward.  The WD is trying something new here, so many claimed it was repetitive and boring.  I plan to remain a fan, but I wish to God someone would burn Carl's hat.
So when did you let your teen start watching this show?  It's been on for 6  years?

First, there were TOO MANY commercials. It is ruining the flow of the show.
But the amount of commercials may not really matter because I am starting to wonder if I am being a bad parent for even allowing my teenager to watch this show. The visual of someone's brain being repeatedly bashed in while their friends watch, with sounds and blood gushes, the skull completely destroyed, and pieces of skin hanging from the bat... it's very graphic and violent. Do I really want that put into our brains, in this world we are living in, fake or not?
My opinion is the show keeps getting darker the longer it's been since all hope of returning to life as they knew it is gone.
I did the exact same thing...sad but I completely agree with you and all the other reviewers who have quit.

I said at the end of last season if they offed Glenn I was done, and I meant it. Plus she show keeps getting darker and darker to the point where I, at least,am no longer interested. I DVRd it and fast-forwarded through most of it, enough to know what happened and that me and TWD broke up tonight. It's permanently deleted from the record schedule as is "Talking Dead." No point watching that now either.

I'm not sure I care but I'm wondering if they lost a lot of viewers either at the end of last season or tonight. Life is too short and there are too many other good TV period, especially on Sunday nights. Thanks for the memories.
It's one episode. Relax.  Now a new story begins. It's not going to be like that every week.

Ha! We knew Glen was going but, after last night I wonder how many agents are calling their clients (like Cudlitz) and recommending a premature skull-bashing.

After last night, I suspect that season 8 will be a complete cast reboot and it won't be because the writers are trying to teach us some deep lesson abut the transient nature of existence. Everyone (with a future) will want to jump ship.
Seriously? There was way less physical violence than a typical episode, most of it was psychological.
Most viewers just don't want to see this much graphic, gratuitous violence. I would think many of the actors are even anxious to move on and distance themselves from what this show has become.

The corpses are, indeed, decomposing before our very eyes. That's why they're making time pass so very slowly, going through uncountable sets of twins for Judith, and despite Chandler Riggs' most amazing growth spurt in cinematic history. The actor has had six or seven birthdays while the character has had maybe two. Look closely at the opening credits from season to season. Some of the older outliers among the walkers are getting very breezy ... a sort of Swiss cheese effect.
I thought they did, but then that would necessitate fresh humans to turn into zombies and there are not that many left to be turned. Good point!
Meh, every time somebody dies they also become a brand new zombie. They need to fix the root cause too

I am too scared to watch this show, but I do wonder whether zombies don't eventually solve the problem by decomposing?

"Release the Flies," I say. And watch the decomposition accelerate. Right?

Walking Dead, you went too far. We all knew you would be killing off major characters, but that was beyond sadistic and horrific, and I had the sound off for parts of it and watched out of the corner of my eye! Killing zombies is one thing, the level of torture to humans in this episode was over the top and unnecessary to depict how evil and sick Negan is. We get it, you don't have to hit us over the head with it repeatedly, pun intended.
Don't kid yourself. You'll be back.
Same feeling exactly. I'm done.

Having never read the comics and never being a fan of gore productions, I can say I have always, for years now enjoyed this show. What I missed was DVRed or caught up with on marathons. The character development was beyond fantastic, and the artfully done, non cheap looking zombie props and prosthetic/special effects always fit well with story, giving The Walking Dead and great feeling of realism, as well as producing great emotions in its audience almost weekly minus a few underdone episodes. The psychology and chemistry between the characters and their strange new world and us the audience was always 4 1/2 stars. And of course those we lost along the way ..well their deaths were not pleasant nor unexpected, but the sole focus was not gore but rather story.
Tonight they went for the graphic shock effect and did it with top dollar props. The label that some might find this program disturbing was an understatement, and the labeling should have been somehow MUCH more graphic to fit what we were about to see, may they be fined! By the time Glens eyes was out of his head but he was still alive I was changing channels. The show has turned to shock and gore to capture it's audience, that is a sign of weakness, of desperation and is offensive to the more intelligent fan base who are watching for sheer, GOOD story, though I am sure it will collect the younger fan base. And inspire some real life murders with baseball bats and barb wire. I will not be back.
It won't be up to  Hillary.  It has to go through Congress.

The deal is being launched now because a Clinton victory is all but certain .

What we are seeing here is the first deal of the Clinton administration to come.

It will be " looked at" and approved - The financial elite made the Clinton's multimillionaires.

Money well invested

To quote the NY Times:

“Everyone is expecting a Clinton victory,” said Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody’s Analytics. “She represents the status quo. They think nothing is going to change, and they’re comfortable with that.’”

http://mobile.nytimes.com/2016/10/24/business/dealbook/att-time-warner-d...

The only tricky one for me today was "Old Spice alternative." I could only think of "Axe," which is obviously wrong. I figured crossings would take care of it until my southern upbringing kicked in.  I entered "welp" for "welt" just based on the phonetic spelling from my wheelhouse. Looking forward to Tuesday!
Our congress has a gold plated, lifetime insurance program. They are not in a position to pass a fair and equitable program for US unless and until WE demand they drop this benefit.
John Edelmann -- the ACA was passed without a single Republican vote.  If you don't like the ACA, you have ONLY the Democrats to blame.  Look it up.

Karen -- The Affordable Care Act, as passed by the Democrats, requires that all Senators and Representatives purchase their health insurance on either their home ACA exchange or on the Washington DC exchange.  The "gold plated plan" is an erroneous liberal myth.

None of us save the rich can afford to pay 10% of our net take home pay for substandard healthcare insurance, yet Clinton says Obamacare is acceptable and her Ivy elite supporters agreee.  The hypocisy is staggering.

Your article should be an eye opener for many people. What a shame that your mother and your family had to suffer through all that unnecessary pain and indignity. I started a career in the health care field with direct patient contact at all stages of life and end of journey situations. I soon realized that I had a very tidy and romanticized view of the death process in a medical setting. I quickly learned it was frequently not fast and many times it was dragged out mercilessly even when the hope of a return to previous level of function and stable health was gone. I think the breakdown occurs when patients and their families are not provided enough information about probable outcomes. Families and patients need an advocate in that setting who can unemotionally give them facts so compassionate decisions can be made. And they need time to process the information. Our Social Workers and Case Managers need the luxury of more time with these patients to make the transition easier.

Lucy:  I found your book on Amazon and bought it as a companion to "A Grief Observed."  Thank you for undertaking to have your husband's book published.  My wife of 39 years succumbed to Ovarian Cancer in January, 2016.  Fortunately, she left behind dozens of little handwritten journals filled with unfinished stories, poems, and observations of life.  Her sister and I are working on getting them transcribed and edited.  It is a wonderfully cathartic undertaking, as we get to continue to hear her voice and experience her complex mind.  I can only imagine you were similarly blessed working on Paul's book.  Thank you for creating this treasure for the grieving to keep discovering.  God Bless.

This may sound corny but here goes: When I have extreme anxiety, I pray. The Lord’s prayer, “The Lord is my shepherd…” works the most effectively for me. I also think of one thing (my mattress, my health, my refrigerator stocked with food) that I’m truly grateful for and I feel instant relief. We all have anxious times, but they’re not debilitating if we find a way to get through them.
